title: Willkommen to Germany’s Caracas
text:
BERLIN — Berliners are famous for their gritty fatalism and what might charitably be described as a unique take on joie de vivre or, less charitably, as outright hostility.

These days, there's no better way to provoke a Berliner's ire than to mention what locals refer to with dismay as der Mietenwahnsinn — the crazy rents.

Berlin’s housing market has tightened considerably in recent years as newcomers from elsewhere in Germany, Europe and beyond have flocked to the German capital. As a result of the influx, rents across much of Berlin have doubled over the past decade and are rising faster than in any other German city, far outpacing income growth.

The development has triggered an emotional debate over the rights of renters and property owners, stirring political ghosts many believed lay buried under the rubble of the Berlin Wall. Facing pressure from the 85 percent of Berliners who rent, the city’s leftist government is likely to enact legislation in the coming weeks straight out of the Hugo Chávez playbook.

Investors and most economists warn that proposed rent controls will only worsen the crisis by stifling investment in new construction and fueling a black market for flats. Anyone with an existing contract in a good location will be loathe to give it up. The only viable way to alleviate the price pressures would be for the city to cut red tape for new construction and offer investors incentives to build.

“This is about values. We want radical change" — Sandrine Woinzeck, activist campaigning for political intervention

Those arguments have largely fallen on deaf ears, however. For many locals, “investor” is a four-letter word. Giving capitalists more influence would be tantamount to treason. For the hardcore Berliner, what’s really at stake isn’t just how much rent people pay, but the city's soul.

“This is about values,” Sandrine Woinzeck, an activist campaigning for political intervention, explained during a recent demonstration. “We want radical change.”

She’s in the right place.

Radical measures

A local initiative recently collected nearly 80,000 signatures supporting the expropriation of apartments owned by large corporate landlords, a step Berlin’s government — a coalition of the Social Democrats, the Left and the Greens — is now considering. Just how much the current owners would receive in compensation isn’t clear.

Not to be outdone, Berlin’s top housing official proposed a set of radical measures last month that would cut many existing rents by more than half and freeze them for five years.

Under the plan, which will go to a city council vote next month, most new rents would be capped well below current market rates. Tenants could apply for a reduction in their existing rent if they spend more than 30 percent of their household income to service the lease, provided the city determines the size of the flat is commensurate with the number of people living in it. The city wants to prevent the well-off and those living alone in large apartments from benefiting.

If these ideas sound like vestiges of Berlin’s recent communist past, that’s because they are. Berlin housing chief Katrin Lompscher, the plan’s mastermind, belongs to the Left party, the successor to the Communist Party that ruled East Germany for decades, and to which she also belonged.

“We want to set a rent level that people can afford,” she said during a public radio discussion earlier this month.

That’s a new challenge for the city.

When I moved to Berlin a decade ago, what struck me most was that Berliners never talked about real estate.

Over the past decade, Berlin’s population has grown by 12 percent to 3.75 million.

Arriving from New York, a city where every chat at a dinner party or playground would inevitably turn to the latest news on rents, housing prices or the conversation killing “if only we’d bought five years ago,” it was jarring to find myself in the company of people for whom the subject of housing was as compelling as a wet schnitzel.

In Berlin — whether in bobo Prenzlauer Berg, trendy Kreuzberg or on the leafy streets of staid Charlottenburg — nice apartments were plentiful and affordable. The rent for the newly renovated pre-war apartment we moved into in 2009 was slightly less than half what we'd paid in Brooklyn for a place less than half the size.

A city of more than 4 million before World War II, Berlin’s population had shrunk by 20 percent by the time the Wall fell and didn’t grow much over the next two decades.

Just about anyone could afford to move to the German capital and in the years that followed my own arrival, it seemed like they did. The city’s cheap rents and reputation as Europe’s capital of cool drew newcomers like moths to the flame.

Over the past decade, Berlin’s population has grown by 12 percent to 3.75 million. The number of Ausländer, foreigners like me, has grown even faster — by 65 percent since 2009 to 759,000.

While the influx has undoubtedly made the city more diverse and dynamic than at any time since the 1920s, it’s also to blame for the rise in rents.

As a result, Berlin has started to sound a lot more like New York, with old-timers complaining about getting “priced out” of trendy neighborhoods and everyone complaining about the cutthroat competition for new flats.

Strike up a conversation with a Berliner these days and it won’t be long before they give you an earful about the dearth of apartments and the scourge of rising rents. Tens of thousands of people have turned out to demonstrate against rising rents in favor of expropriating large real estate investors in recent months.

The art of real estate

The housing woes are even driving the discussion in the city’s burgeoning post-modernist arts scene.

Over the summer, artist Clemens Schöll unveiled an installation he calls “From one who set out to find an apartment in Berlin. A drama of automation in three acts.”

In act two — called “The Promise of the Bot” — Schöll, who is also an IT specialist, offered Berliners free access to a program that trolls real estate websites and automatically sends applications for apartments that meet an individual’s requirements. The Berlin market has become so competitive that some ads are online for an hour or less before the landlord, overloaded by applications, removes them. Schöll’s tool levels the playing field.

Schöll hoped the project would highlight the societal tensions automation creates between those who are pushed out of their jobs and apartments by gentrification and those who have new opportunities as a result of technological advances.

That deeper meaning is likely lost on most users, however, for whom Schöll’s innovation is simply a useful weapon to combat der Mietenwahnsinn.

Virtually no one is spared the effects of Berlin’s dog-eat-dog real estate world, a reality I’ve discovered manifests itself in surprising ways.

Last weekend, a neighbor stopped by to apologize for a group of kids that had been screaming in the courtyard of our building at lunchtime. Her landlord is trying to sell her apartment to cash in on the booming property market and the neighbor was hoping to scare off potential buyers during an open house that day.

The neighbor has been living in the apartment for 10 years, but once it is sold, she and her family are likely to get kicked out. Finding a new place in central Berlin for a good price will be next to impossible, even if the city government pushes through rent control reform.

“I’m losing it,” she confided.

One by one the residents in our building have faced a similar fate.

My family and I were the first.

After a decade of paying bargain-basement rent, der Mietenwahnsinn left us with only one option: We bought.
description: Berliners never used to talk about real estate. Now it’s inescapable.
